intro: Libanotis sibirica, commonly known as Siberian bellflower, is a perennial herb native to the cold climates of Siberia and Central Asia. It belongs to the Campanulaceae family and is characterized by its striking blue or violet bell-shaped flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with lance-shaped leaves that are hairy beneath. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in rocky or alpine environments. Due to its ornamental value and adaptability, it is cultivated in gardens in temperate regions.
